initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.

The soldier, Sgt. Black, was stationed in South Korea and had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas. However, instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok, Russia, to visit his girlfriend.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt. Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property. He is currently being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

Sgt. Black's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend. She pleaded with the Russians not to torture or hurt her son, and expressed her concern for his well-being.

The arrest of Sgt. Black is the latest in a series of incidents involving Americans being detained in Russia. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges, and former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020. Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.

The case of Sgt. Black highlights the risks of travelling abroad without official clearance, and the potential consequences of not following protocol. It also raises questions about the security of American soldiers stationed abroad, and the measures in place to protect them.

As the case of Sgt. Black unfolds, it will be important to monitor the developments and ensure that his rights are protected. It is also crucial for the US government to continue advocating for the release of all Americans detained in Russia, and to work towards improving relations with the country.

A US soldier has been arrested in Russia for theft and is now facing serious charges. The soldier, Sergeant Black, was stationed in South Korea and was in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas. However, instead of returning to the US, he traveled through China to Vladivostok, Russia, to visit his girlfriend.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on May 3 that Sergeant Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property. He is currently being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

However, the story takes an unexpected turn when it is revealed that Sergeant Black's girlfriend is a Russian spy. The Russian government had used her to lure Sergeant Black to Russia, where he was arrested and charged with espionage.

Sergeant Black's arrest highlights the potential dangers of American soldiers engaging in romantic relationships with foreign nationals, particularly those from countries with unstable political situations.
